Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story:
This Sunday morning, my granddaughter sat beside me at the kitchen table, her eyes searching mine for answers. She was starting high school next week, nervous about making friends and finding her place. As her grandmother, I felt the weight of her trust, the expectation to share wisdom from my own tangled journey through life. I wanted to give her all the time she needed, to listen and guide her gently.

But the church bells echoed faintly from down the street, a reminder of my other promise—to my faith and my community. As a Christian, I was expected to be present at Sunday worship, to join in prayer and fellowship, to set an example of devotion for my family. I glanced at the clock, feeling the minutes slip away. My heart tugged in two directions: toward the granddaughter who needed me now, and toward the sanctuary where I was also needed. I wrestled with the guilt of possibly letting someone down, unsure which role should take precedence this morning.
